Literature Review: Behavioral inhibition (BI) is a temperament profile characterized by heightened reactivity to sensory stimuli in infancy, reticence toward social cues in childhood, and the later emergence of social anxiety in adolescence. The antecedents and consequences of BI have been extensively studied over the past four decades, with research indicating that BI is a significant predictor of social anxiety disorder (SAD) in adolescence (Kendall et al., 2007; Lahey et al., 2007). However, the underlying mechanisms that contribute to the development of BI and its consequences remain poorly understood. This review proposes that a two-hit model can supplement prior work to better understand these developmental pathways. Specifically, time-limited experiences ('hits') centered in infancy and adolescence stress idiosyncratic BI-linked processes that uniquely trigger the developmental pathway from temperament to disorder. In this review, we will examine the role of caregiver distress in infancy, social reorientation in adolescence, and their impact on malleable attentional and cognitive systems in the development of BI and anxiety.
